As Chair of the #WomenVetsTaskForce, I would like to share this video, produced by a resident of #VenturaCounty, recognizing the extraordinary women of the Six Triple Eight and honor the service and sacrifice of these military heroes ‚§µÔ∏è
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e5Fc8RVH5f4
The Six Triple-Eight was the largest black women‚Äôs unit deployed in World War II, and only received formal recognition for their service decades after the war ended.

Even when facing harsh weather and constant scrutiny from supervisors, the battalion worked around to clock and soon became the most productive mail service throughout Europe. The unit was allotted six months to complete their mission. The Six Triple Eight did it in three.

Adams developed an incredible system that allowed the unit to sort and deliver the backlog of over 17 million pieces of mail. The servicewomen worked 24 hours a day, seven days a week, and in three rotating eight-hour shifts. Each shift sorted and processed 65,000 pieces of mail.
In response, the Women‚Äôs Army Corps formed the all-black Six Triple Eight (6888) Battalion to deliver millions of pieces of mail and restore high spirits to troops across Europe.

In the height of World War II, oversees military personnel faced a serious problem: due to a six-month backlog of mail, soldiers were not receive letters or packages from loved ones, which plummeted morale.

‚ÄúThe best WAC unit ever sent into foreign theater,‚Äù said Lt. Col. Charity Adams, the first African-American commanding officer in the Women‚Äôs Army Corps to be deployed to a theater of war. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FbBm2WLUYAImXz6.jpg
